subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I have suggested simple refactorings for once the Original Questioner has learned from Craig s advice/changes. ... Simple refactoring #1: replace these
messageBody:
PARDEY, CRAIG wrote:

> I can see a few problems (ignoring the need for refactoring). I have
> changed them in such a way that the test now works for values other than 2.
>
> The things I changed:
> 1. Removed the quotes from the suite
> 2. Split main() into main() and setUp() so the LanguageVector main is
> always called.
>
> The code is attached.

I have suggested simple refactorings for once the Original Questioner
has learned from Craig's advice/changes.

>
> import junit.framework.Test;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
>
> public class LanguageVectorTest extends TestCase
> {
> LanguageVector langvect = new LanguageVector();
> public void testlangvect()
> {
> System.out.println("value of langvect.length" +
> LanguageVector.length);
> assertEquals(2, LanguageVector.length);
> assertEquals("TOMCAT", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(0));
> assertEquals("EJB", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(1));
> assertEquals("COBOL", LanguageVector.list.elementAt(2));
> }

Simple refactoring #1: replace these assertions with
assertEquals(expectedLanguages, actualLanguages), where expectedLanguage
is a LanguageVector with values TOMCAT, EJB, COBOL. This means
implementing equals().

Simple refactoring #2: TOMCAT and EJB are not languages, therefore
rename LanguageVector to something else.

Simple refactoring #3: Vector is for people stuck in 1999 (JDK 1.1).
Rename LanguageVector to XXXList, where XXX is the name you choose from
refactoring #2.

Simple refactoring #4: Never, ever, ever use System.out.println() in a
test. Make an assertion instead.

The rest is snipped.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
